# BEGIN of field descriptions
# id: The database primary key.
# hip: The star's ID in the Hipparcos catalog
# hd: The star's ID in the Henry Draper catalog
# hr: The star's ID in the Harvard Revised catalog
column2: which is the same as its number in the Yale Bright Star Catalog.

column1: # gl: The star's ID in the third edition of the Gliese Catalog of Nearby Stars.
# bf: The Bayer / Flamsteed designation
column2: primarily from the Fifth Edition of the Yale Bright Star Catalog. This is a combination of the two designations. The Flamsteed number
column4: is given first; then a three-letter abbreviation for the Bayer Greek letter; the Bayer superscript number
column6: the three-letter constellation abbreviation. Thus Alpha Andromedae has the field value "21Alp And"
column7: and Kappa1 Sculptoris (no Flamsteed number) has "Kap1Scl".

column1: # ra
column2: dec: The star's right ascension and declination

column1: # proper: A common name for the star
column2: such as "Barnard's Star" or "Sirius". I have taken these names primarily from the Hipparcos project's web site
column3: which lists representative names for the 150 brightest stars and many of the 150 closest stars. I have added a few names to this list. Most of the additions are designations from catalogs mostly now forgotten (e.g.
column6: and Gould ["G."]) except for certain nearby stars which are still best known by these designations.

column1: # dist: The star's distance in light years. A value >= 32620000 indicates missing or dubious (e.g.
# pmra
column2: pmdec: The star's proper motion in right ascension and declination

column1: # rv: The star's radial velocity in km/sec
# mag: The star's apparent visual magnitude.
# absmag: The star's absolute visual magnitude (its apparent magnitude from a distance of 10 parsecs).
# spect: The star's spectral type
# ci: The star's color index (blue magnitude - visual magnitude)
# x
column3: z: The Cartesian coordinates of the star
column4: in a system based on the equatorial coordinates as seen from Earth. +X is in the direction of the vernal equinox (at epoch 2000)
column6: and +Y in the direction of R.A. 6 hours

column1: # vx
column3: vz: The Cartesian velocity components of the star
column4: in the same coordinate system described immediately above. They are determined from the proper motion and the radial velocity (when known). The velocity unit is parsecs per year; these are small values (around 1 millionth of a parsec per year)
column5: but they enormously simplify calculations using parsecs as base units for celestial mapping.

column1: # rarad
column5: and proper motions in radians per year.

column1: # bayer: The Bayer designation as a distinct value
# flam: The Flamsteed number as a distinct value
# con: The standard constellation abbreviation
# comp
column3: base: Identifies a star in a multiple star system. comp = ID of companion star
column4: comp_primary = ID of primary star for this component
column5: and base = catalog ID or name for this multi-star system. Currently only used for Gliese stars.

column1: # lum: Star's luminosity as a multiple of Solar luminosity.
# var: Star's standard variable star designation
# var_min
column3: for variables. This value is based on the Hp magnitudes for the range in the original Hipparcos catalog
column4: adjusted to the V magnitude scale to match the "mag" field.
